title: Practical PostgreSQL
segmentation: So my name is Simon Riggs.

I'm the CTO of 2nd Quadrant and I'm going to talk to you today about a technology called Postgre SQL or post codes and now my background is that I've been working in what we now call big data for 25 years and over that time it has always been my experience that the database has been the enabling technology by which we deliver the data solutions.
So for example, early data warehousing technologies, early implementations have all relied very heavily on the quality of the database software to deliver that solution.
So what I'd like to talk to you about is a technology.
That I'm currently working on, which is called post codes.
So Postgres database service software and its primary distinguishing characteristic which you will find important is that it's production quality.
Open source software.
OK, there's lots of open source software out there, but very little of it is production quality.
And what I'd like to do is explain to you some of the areas that Postgres has got features that will be of great use to you both in your research and the dissemination of that research.
So the primary thought that I'm trying to get across in 15 minutes is that post crazy is a practical choice for European data.
So who you?
This is post grades and what do they use it for?
Well, can everybody read?
The slides, can you guys at the back read those slides?
Yeah, so I'm not going to read out all of the slides.

I'll let you read most of the words on my slides while I'm speaking, so there's a significant worldwide customer base for Postgrads and the people that use it are not just using it on the desktops, they're using it in server farms.
I'm talking about hundreds and hundreds of deployments in each of these companies, so Nokia McAfee.

It's also being used in appliances, so there's a significant number of databases which are spread out across thousands of different users by those particular companies, so we're talking in aggregate of hundreds of thousands of server installs across the world.
What are the features that people are using it?
Well, it's a full strength database.
It's got very high-quality synchronous replication.
Lots of data protection facilities, and it's got everything you need to build both a data collection and a data analytics data environment.
It has a significant number of innovative features.
It was born in research 20 years ago, but we're still innovating.
There's a, there's a new release every single year, and there's a significant number of unique innovations in the product.
For example, SP Gist indexes, which are the fastest known mechanism for doing geographical index look ups, OK?
And that is a feature that is not available in any other production software anywhere in the world.
So that currently means that we can do location aware queries on post queries, perhaps 10 times faster than other databases.
We're the first to implement things like range data types as well, so.
Postgres is an innovative product.
It has a significant.
Capability over and above what you may have heard people talk about the traditional relational database.
Well, Postgres has many, many features that don't fall into that category.
It supports complex datatypes, complex user defined data types.
It supports arrays, nested records, range data types.
It acts as a key value store.
You can store all sorts of complex data in it using.
XML, Jason and we fully support fulltext indexing mechanisms that are well in advance of a lot of other systems.
Moreover than that, you can write SQL to access the database that's recursive, so you can actually write SQL queries that can search networks.
It can search linked data of significant size by Spidering out.
Into a whole database full of XML, if that's what you're after doing.
We also support recursive write operations, so you can issue an update statement that affects a particular set of network nodes in a in a complex data structure.
So that's just some of the things that you can do.
And.
Most, I suppose, annoyingly, is that quite often people talk about Postgres is simply being a traditional database.
Well, it kind of was a few years ago, but we are moving forwards.
We've got something like 25 man years every year of effort going into Postgres development, and there's a new release coming out every year.
So.
Why post grades?
Well, Postgres is open source and there are a significant number of commercial variants of the software available.
Park cell has just been used by Amazon to create its redshift service.
For example, IBM uses a Postgres developed derivative.
EMC uses a post codes derivative, and there's also a significant number of large scale research projects that have.
Been based directly upon the Postgres codebase as a way of extending and exploring database technology.
And I'd like to highlight here and now that the European Union.
FP7 has also funded significant developments on Postgres.
It funded synchronous replication automatic fail over a low energy power saving mode, all via the forecast project.
Work in progress.

Currently with Postgres, we're currently working on something called bidirectional replication which will allow us to more easily do data collection, say from handheld devices, direct through to server farms for data collection, but also for analytics.
And most importantly we have a big project running now called the Axle project which stands for.
Analytics of extremely large European data, and that's a three year project that we're just entering the six month 6th month of now.
So we've got 2 1/2 years still to run on that project and that is going to bring us significant developments.
One of the significant developments is we're going to have row level security within the database, so that's military grade security security in the database.
So all of the big data that we talk about.
Mostly pertains to individuals in some shape or form, and we're going to be able to protect the privacy of that data right at source.
That is very important.

Not only that, we're working on features to improve the handling of very large data stores, but also improving the speed of access against those data stores, both with software algorithms and with hardware optimizations.
And along with that, we're building visual analytics capability into the database and associated software.
That's called Axel, and there's a website called Axle Project dot EU that describes that in a little bit more detail.
If you've got anytime.
So just as I'm coming to the end of.
My talk, I'd like to ask you to do a number of things.
First of all, use Postgres in your projects.
Use postgres.
In your research.
It is freely available.
It's fully documented.
The documentation is now 1500 pages of a four paper.
If you printed it so it's extensive software, well documented, highly robust.
My company second Quadrant is busy expanding the codebase, as are many other people, and I'd like to work with you in research consortia to further extend those capabilities if that's possible.

If you're interested in the actual project and what we're doing, and you'd like to stay in touch with that, then I would encourage you to send an email to register at Axel Project Dot EU and will put you on a mailing list where we can send out regular newsletters to update you on the work that we're doing and the successes that we have as they come.
And if you don't manage to do any of those things, then I would say.
One last thing, which is try to disseminate your work as open source, because it really does work as a mechanism for disseminating useful software.
It encourages very broad adoption of that software, and my company is a good example of proof that it can be economically justifiable to work on open source as well.
So thank you very much.
My name is Monica Franceschini and I also work for an open source project for being business.
Intelligence is probably I, and my question is, how do you approach a big data?
You mean that it is possible to deploy Postgres in a distributed environment or gluster?
Or how do you manage the big data volumes that other database do?
Yeah, I mean the customer asked me yesterday what do we do when the database runs out and we hit the limits of the database?
Obviously that's a problem because there isn't any technology that doesn't have a kind of some kind of upper limit.
At the moment we don't support massive massively parallel implementations, so as a single data store there are effective limits to what we can currently achieve.
That's one of the areas that we're working towards.
What we've currently done as part of the actual project is look at.
Algorithmic ways that allow us to manage the big data without needing to do parallel query for example?
So Postgres does not yet do everything I can think of.
A database should be able to do with probably 5 to 10 years away from that and over the course of those five to 10 years.
Will probably think of another five or ten years worth of things to do.

So the thing that I'd like to get your attention on is that databases are an enabling technology, but you also have to invest in further advances in the database technology alongside other advances in other software so.
So what one question you mentioned that in this actual project you are introducing analytics, so can you tell what type of analytics on on what data modalities?
So like text, graphs, images and what kind of operators you would introduce this one question.
The second question would be how these future version of Postgres compares with this.
No SQL databases which are, well, you know popular nowadays.

So this let me speak into the microphone so this this quite a few questions there in terms of the actual project, what we're working on is we're analyzing the results against a number of different datasets, so it's not just a single data set that we're analyzing, and it's not just tabular data that we're working with, so there is a significant effort to make that very broad based, as I said.

Postgres supports very well specified geographical data manipulation functions, including indexing and all sorts of operators designed to make sensible use of that, and will be including that within the research.
In terms of how it relates to no SQL databases.
If you wish to analyze data, you need to have some kind of way of accessing a data store for analytical purposes.
At the moment, SQL is far and away the most dominant access language, and should there be in the future other access languages for data, I'm sure we would support them.
So the access language is not something we're wedded to.
It's an implementation detail.
Thanks, thanks a lot and you, but you do need an access language.
You can't just not have one.
So thanks.
Thanks again for the for the talk and.
